notesStmt.note: Includes, besides reports of important events, various public documents of 1653-1656, notably the Instrument of government (published in 1653 with title "Articles signed by His Highness Oliver Cromwell ..."), lists members of Cromwell's Parliaments in 1653 and 1656, and "An act declaring what offences shall be adjudged treason", of 17 July 1649.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A COPY of the LETTER FROM His Excellency the Lord Generall CROMWELL, SENT TO THE MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT.
Called to take upon them the Tru≈øt of the Government of this Common-wealth.
WHICH Began on Munday the Fourth of June, 1653. The day appointed by the Letters of Summons from his Excellency the Lord Gen. Cromwell, for the meeting of the≈øe GENTLEMEN.
LONDON: Printed by M. S. for Tho: Jenner at the South-entrance of the Royall Exchange. 1656

div.head: A COPY of the LETTER From his Exccellency the Lord Generall Cromwell, ≈øent to the Members of Parliament, called to take upon them the Tru≈øt of the Government of this Common-wealth.
div.p: FOra≈ømuch as upon the di≈ø≈øolution of the late Parliament, it became nece≈ø≈øary that the Peace, Safety and Goverment of this Common-wealth ≈øhould be provided for; and in order thereunto, divers per≈øons fearing God, and of approved fidelity and hone≈øty, are by my Selfe, with the advice of My Coun≈øel of Officers nominated, to whom the Charge and Tru≈øt of ≈øo weighty Affaires is to be committed. And having good a≈ø≈øurance of your love to, and courage for God, and the intere≈øt of his Cau≈øe, and of the good people of this Common-wealth, I Oliver Cromwell, Captain Generall, and Commander in Chief of all the Armies and Forces rai≈øed and to be rai≈øed within this Common-wealth, do hereby ≈øummon and require you, being one of the per≈øons nominated, per≈øonally to be, and appear at the Coun≈øell Chamber commonly known, or called by the name of the Councell Chamber at White Hall, within the City of We≈øtmin≈øter, upon the fourth day of July next, en≈øuing the date hereof, then and there to take upon you the ≈øaid Tru≈øt, unto which you are hereby called, and appointed to ≈øerve as a Member for the County of ‚Äî And hereof you are not to fail. Given under My hand and ≈øeale the ‚Äî day of June, 1653.

div.head: Monday, June 4. 1653.
div.p:
This being the day appointed by the Letters of S ‚Ä¢ mmons, from his Excellency the Lord General Cromwell, for the meeting
of tho≈øe Gentlemen that were called to the Supream Authority, they met accordingly in the Councell Chamber, where being entred the Room, above one hundred and twenty in number, and being ≈øet round about the Table, the Lord Generall ≈øtanding by the window oppo≈øite to the middle of the Table and having as many of the Army-Officers as the room could well contein, on his right hand and on his left, his Lord≈øhip made a very grave Chri≈øtian and ≈øea≈øonable ≈øpeech and Exhortation, wherein he breifly recounted the many great and wondrous mercyes of God towards this Nation, and the Series of providence wherein the pre≈øence of God did wonderfully appear in carrying on this Cau≈øe, and bringing affaires into the pre≈øent condition, beyond all expectation; a≈øcribing the glory of all to God alone.

He ≈øet forth al≈øo in particular the progre≈ø≈øe of affaires ≈øince the famous victory at Worce≈øter, wherein that Arch Enemy of this nation was wholly ≈øubdued. He likewi≈øe laid down the actings of the Army there upon, after divers applications to the Parliament, and much being wanting, and forbearance, together with the grounds and nece≈ø≈øity of their di≈ø≈øolving the ≈øaid Parliament, which his Excellency declared to be for the pre≈øevation of this Cau≈øe, and the intere≈øt of all hone≈øt men who have been ingaged therein.

Moreover, he very amply held forth the clearene≈ø≈øe of the Call given to the pre≈øent Members to take the Supream Authority, and did from the Scriptures exhort them to their duties and incourage them therein, de≈øiring that a tendernes might be u≈øed towards all godly and con≈øcientious per≈øons, of what judgment and under what form ≈øoever.

Which being ended, his Lord≈øhip produced an in≈øtrument under his own hand and ≈øeale, wherby he did with the advi≈øe of his Officer, devolve and entru≈øt the Supream Authority and Government of this Common-wealth, into the hands of the per≈øons then met, who or any forty of them are to be held and acknowledged the Supream Authority of the Nation, unto whom all per≈øons within the ≈øame, and the Territories thereunto belonging are to yeild obedience and ≈øubjection. And they are not to ≈øit longer then the 3 day of November,
1654. Three months before their di≈ø≈øolution they are to make choyce of other per≈øons to ≈øucceed them, who are not to ≈øit longer then a twelve month; but it is left to them to take care for a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion in Government: which In≈øtrument being delivered to the per≈øons afore≈øaid, his Lord≈øhip commended them to the Grace of God.

This being done his Excellency and his Officers withdrew; and the ≈øaid per≈øons ≈øo met, having the Supream Authority put into their hands, after ≈øome ≈øhort ≈øpace, adjourned till the next morning eight a clock, and appointed to meet in the old Parliament Hou≈øe there to ≈øeek God for direction in this great work, and for his pre≈øence and ble≈ø≈øing therein. Hereupon, without doing any further bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, they all departed.

div.head: An ACT Declaring what Offences ≈øhall be adjudged Trea≈øon.
div.p: BE it Enacted by this pre≈øent Parliament, and by the Authority of the ≈øame, That if any per≈øon ≈øhall maliciou≈øly or advi≈øedly publi≈øh by writing, Printing, or openly declaring that the ≈øaid Government is Tyrannicall, u≈øurped, or unlawfull; Or that the Commons in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled are not the ≈øupream Authority of this Nation, or ≈øhall plot, contrive or endeavour to ≈øtir up or rai≈øe force again≈øt the pre≈øent Government, or for the ≈øubver≈øion or alteration of the ≈øame, and ≈øhall declare the ≈øame by an open deed, that then every ≈øuch offence ≈øhall be taken, deemed and adjudged by Authority of this Parliament to be high Trea≈øon.

That if any per≈øon ≈øhall maliciou≈øly and advi≈øedly plot or endeavour the ≈øubver≈øion of the ≈øaid Keepers of the Liberties of England, or the Councell of State, and the ≈øame ≈øhall declare by an open deed, or ≈øhall move any per≈øon or per≈øons for the doing thereof, or ≈øtir up the people to ri≈øe again≈øt them, or either of them, they or either of their
Authorityes, every ≈øuch offence ≈øhall be taken, deemed, and declared to be high Trea≈øon.

If any per≈øon not being an Officer, Souldier, or member of the Army, ≈øhall plot, contrive, or endeavour to ≈øtir up any mutiny in the ≈øaid Army, or withdraw any Souldiers or Officers from their obedience to their Superiour Officers, or from the pre≈øent Government as afore≈øaid, or ≈øhall procure, invite, aid, or a≈ø≈øi≈øt any Forreigners or ≈øtrangers to invade England or Ireland, or ≈øhall adhere to any Forces rai≈øed by the Enemies of the Parliament, Common-wealth, or Ke ‚Ä¢ per; of the Liberties of England, or if any per≈øon ≈øhall coun ‚Ä¢ efeit the Great Seale of England for the time being, u≈øed and appointed by Authority of Parliament, every ≈øuch offence ≈øhall be taken to be high Trea≈øon, and al≈øo forfeit unto the u≈øe of the Common-wealth, all and ≈øingular his or their Lands, Tenements, and Heriditaments, Goods and Chattells: Provided alwayes that no per≈øons ≈øhall be indicted and arraigned for any of the Offences mentioned in this Act, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øuch Offenders ≈øhall be indicted or pro≈øecuted for the ≈øame within one year after the Offence committed.

That if any per≈øon ≈øhall counterfeit the money of this Common-wealth, or ≈øhall bring any fal≈øe money into this Land, counterfeit or other like to the money of this Common-wealth, knowing the money to be fal≈øe, to merchandize or make payment, in deceit of the people of this Nation: Or if any per≈øon ≈øhall hereafter fal≈øly forge and counterfeit any ≈øuch kind of Coyn of Gold or Silver, as is not the proper Coyne of this Common-wealth, and is or ≈øhall be currant within this Nation by con≈øent of the Parliament, or ≈øuch as ≈øhall be by them authorized thereunto: Or ≈øhall bring from the parts beyond the Seas into this Common-wealth, or into any the dominions of the ≈øame, any ≈øuch fal≈øe and counterfeit Coyne of money being currant within the ≈øame as is above ≈øaid, knowing the ≈øame to be fal≈øe, to the intent to offer or make payment by merchandize or otherwi≈øe, or ≈øhall impaire, dimini≈øh, fal≈øifie, clip, wa≈øh, round, file, ≈øcale, or lighten for wicked lucre or gaines ≈øake, any the proper moneys of this Common-wealth, or any other Realm; allowed and ≈øuffered
to be currant: All ≈øuch Offences adjudged high Trea≈øon, their coun≈øellours, procurers, aiders and abettors being convicted ≈øhall ≈øuffer paines of death. It ≈øhall not extend to or be adjudged to make any corruption of blood to any of the Heires, or to make the wife to forfeit her Dour, or her title, action, or intere≈øt in the ≈øame. July 17. 1649.

div.head: A Relation of the Mutiny on Tue≈øday the 22 of Nov: 1653. in the New Exchange, of the Portugall Amba≈ø≈øadors Followers, &c.
div.p: THis night was a great Mutiny at the New Exchange in the Strand, ≈øuch as hath ≈øcarce ever been the like: The bu≈øine≈ø≈øe upon the be≈øt information that I can have from tho≈øe who were pre≈øent in part of the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and have conferred with others upon the whole, is this.

On Munday night (which was the night before) three of the Portugall Amba≈ø≈øadours family, whereof his brother was one, being at the New Exchange, they talking in French ≈øpake of ≈øuch di≈øcour≈øe of Tran≈øactions of ≈øome Engli≈øh Affaires, which Col. Gerhard, Sir Gilbert Gerhards brother, under≈øtanding the French Tongue, hearing, told them very civilly,
that they did not repre≈øent the ≈øtories they ≈øpake of right; whereupon one of the Portugalls gave him the lie, upon that they began to ju≈øtle, and all three fell upon Col. Gerhard, and threw him down, and got upon him, but tho he be but a little man, yet he threw him off that was upon him, and ≈øo was bu≈øtling with him a good while; there were ≈øome Gentlemen there, but knew not who it was they ≈øo a≈ø≈øaulted, and ≈øo ne'r medled with them, and yet one of the Portugalls with his Dagger ≈øtab'd Col. Gerhard in the ≈øhoulder, and hurt him ≈øore; but afterwards Mr. Anfrazer ≈øpake to the Portugalls, that it was not civill nor hand≈øome for ≈øo many to fall upon one, three to one being very unequall, and endeavoured to pull one of them off, and ≈øo to per≈øwade them to cea≈øe, and thereby he came to ≈øee who it was they had a≈ø≈øaulted, who finding it to be Col. Gerhard which he knew well, and ≈øeeing them ≈øtill pur≈øue their rage upon him, he drew to relieve him, and after ≈øome bu≈øtle the Portugalls went away, one of them having a cut upon his cheek; and that night afterwards near twenty of their Attendants came to the Exchange, and would have quarrel'd with any body, and ≈øome cuffing there was by ≈øome, but not much more that night, for it was late, and they returned home.

On Tue≈øday night, came about fifty of the Portugalls againe to the New Exchange, of which number were the Amba≈ø≈øadours brother, and two Knights of Malta, and they were led on by a Portugall in Buffe, whom they call Captaine, one well known to ≈øome in the Exchange, and they had generally double Arms, all or mo≈øt part of them ≈øwords and pi≈øtolls, and coats of Male, or Armour, ≈øome one thing, ≈øome another, to pre≈øerve their bodies from ≈øwords entring upon them. They had al≈øo two or three Coaches that brought Ammunition, in which were hand Granadoes and Bottles, and ≈øome little barrells of powder, and bullets, and other nece≈ø≈øaries if occa≈øion was. They had al≈øo ≈øome Boats ready to attend them at the water ≈øide, if occa≈øion was for them al≈øo.

Thus they came with a re≈øolution to fall upon every Engli≈øh Gentleman they ≈øhould find in or about the Exchange;
and entring in with this equipage the people were exceedingly frighted. For fir≈øt came in the Captaine in the Buffe, who led them, and after him the Portugall Amba≈ø≈øadors brother, and the Knights of Malta, and ≈øo the re≈øt, all with drawn ≈øwords, and in ≈øo furious a po≈øture, as if they intended to kill every body they met with, that ≈øtood before them.

Hereupon the people fled into the ≈øhops in the Exchange to ≈øhelter them≈øelves, and all that did not ≈øo they fell upon, though no man gave them the lea≈øt affront, yet they pi≈øtol'd and cut, and wounded many.

Mr. Greneway a Gentleman of Grayes Inne, Son to the Lady Greneway was there with his Si≈øter and a Gentlewoman whom he was to have married, who de≈øired them two to ≈øta ‚Ä¢ d up in a ≈øhop where he ≈øaw them ≈øafe, and they would have had him to have ≈øtaid with them, but he ≈øaid he would onely goe ≈øee what was the matter; but he was no ≈øooner parted from them, but immediately the word being given by the Portugall Captaine in Buff ‚Ä¢ , which was Safa, which was the word when they were to fall on, without any affront offered towards them, one of them pi≈øtol'd him, and ≈øhot him in the head, and he is dead of his wounds: and many others t ‚Ä¢ ey have dangerou≈øly wounded. Col. Mayo had twelve upon him at once, yet drew his ≈øword, and fought with them as long as he was able to hold his ≈øword in his hand, which being cut, he was forced to let his ≈øword fall, and then cut and wounded him in many places. Mr. Tho: Howard, Mr. Carter, and divers others were wounded pa≈ø≈øing by.

The Hor≈øe at the Mu≈øe had taken alarm before they returned, and returning home, pa≈ø≈øing by the Mu≈øe, ≈øome of the Hor≈øe mo ing towards them, ≈øome of them di≈øcharged pi≈øtols towards the Hor≈øe, and the re≈øt run home to the Amba≈ø≈øadours hou≈øe; but the Hor≈øe guards took ≈øome of them and carried them into the Mu≈øe, and ≈øent word thereof to the Lord Generall; and a party of hor≈øe pur≈øued them, and be≈øet the Amba≈ø≈øadors hou≈øe. And Commi≈ø. Gen. Whalley ≈øent into the Amba≈ø≈øador, acquainted him with this horrible attempt and bloody murther of his Followers, and ≈øhewed him
his men they had taken pri≈øoners, and required the chiefe of the re≈øt of them to be delivered in the hands of Ju≈øtice, which the Amba≈ø≈øador was loath to doe. But ≈øeeing he could not baffle them, to ≈øtop the cour≈øe of ju≈øtce in ≈øo horrible a bloody bu≈øine≈ø≈øe as that had been, he delivered up his brother and one of the Knights of Malta, and ≈øome others, ≈øuch as they had then information was chiefe, and promi≈øed to ≈øecure the re≈øt to be forth-coming any of them when they ≈øhould be demanded. After which the Amba≈ø≈øador made his Addre≈ø≈øe to the Lord Generall, and chiefly for his brother, but his Excellency told him that it did concern the publick, and therefore his Addre≈ø≈øes mu≈øt be to the Parliament and Councell of State. It is ≈øuch a horrible bu≈øine≈ø≈øe that his Excellency would not meddle with him in it.
The Portugals that are in cu≈øtody are pri≈øoners at Jame≈øes, and the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is under Examination before the Councell of State.

div.head: For his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector of the Common-wealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
The Declaration, with the humble Addre≈ø≈øe of the Generalls, and the ≈øeverall Commanders pre≈øent in the Fleet, by them ≈øeverally ≈øub≈øcribed.
div.p: THat the≈øe Nations of England, Scotland, and Ireland, having been for ≈øome years like the Bu≈øh which burned, but is not con≈øumed: And though the Nations round about us ≈øtand gazing on to ≈øee us made a de≈øolation, as well as a hi≈ø≈øing unto them; yet we are hitherto by the mighty power of the Lord, and his wonderfull out-goings among≈øt us, made rather an a≈øtoni≈øhment in our pre≈øervation, then a reproach, by our ruine and deva≈øtation.

In which great Work of the Lord we acknowledge with thankfulne≈ø≈øe your Highne≈ø≈øe hath been a glorious In≈øtrument,
and hath undergone many hard≈øhips and hazard of all that was near and dear unto you, even to life it ≈øelfe; and under≈øtanding by providence your Highne≈ø≈øe is intru≈øted with, and hath excepted of the Protection of this Common-wealth in the Government thereof.

We are in hopes that the Lord intends a ≈øettlement of Peace to the≈øe poor di≈øtracted Nations, and that our ≈øelves with all the people of the Lord ≈øhall enjoy and partake of the ≈øame under your Highne≈ø≈øe Prot ‚Ä¢ ction, according to the Rule of the Lord Je≈øus. And therefore we have thought it nece≈ø≈øary as a duty incumbent on us, to Declare that we ≈øhall willingly be obedient and faithfull to your Highne≈øs, in performance of your great Tru≈øt, and al≈øo in the utmo≈øt hazzard of our lives (with what el≈øe is near and dear unto us) be ≈øerviceable unto you, in the ≈øtation the Lord hath placed you, again≈øt yours and the Common-wealths Enemies, in our ≈øeverall places and capacities, during our Employments.

And having had good te≈øtimony of your great affection and earning bow ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ls after the weale of Gods people, wee are emboldned an ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ncouraged in all humility to make this following Addr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

That your ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hne≈ø≈øe will be plea≈øed to have a more ≈øpeciall eye of fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ unto them above all others, in regard they are near and dear unto him, who is the Lord of Lords, and King of Kings, even our Lord Je≈øus For which cau≈øe he is a≈øhamed to call them brethren; And doe humbly apprehend that their priviledges will be your priviledge. And to account of them as of your greate≈øt Jewells, which will doubtle≈ø≈øe turne to your great advantage.

And hereby you will for time to come not onely ingage their hearts unto you, who in times pa≈øt have not ≈øtood at a di≈øtance from you, but your Highne≈ø≈øe will al≈øo ingage the great Jehovah, your and their Father, to be be a refuge, ≈øhield, and defence unto you, as well as an everla≈øting re≈øt for you, when all the ≈øtorms of this Common-wealth ≈øhall cea≈øe, which is and ≈øhall be the unfeigned prayers of,

closer.signed: Your Highne≈ø≈øe mo≈øt humble and faithfull Servants. Signed by the Generalls and the ≈øeverall Commanders pre≈øent in the Fleet.

p.hi: Monday Dec. 12. 1653. It being moved, That the ≈øitting of this Parliament was not for the peace of the Common-wealth; and that therefore it was requi≈øite to deliver up unto the Lord Generall Cromwell the powers which they received from him; and ≈øeconded by ≈øeverall other Members, and the Speaker with many of the Members departed to Whitehall, being the greater number, and did by a writing under their hands re≈øigne unto his Excellency their ≈øaid powers.

div.head: Saturday, Decemb. 10. 1653.
div.p: The Parliament this day re≈øumed the Debate upon the Report made this day from the Committee of Tythes, which is as followes.

1. That it be repre≈øented to the Parliament as the be≈øt way for ejecting ignorant, prophane, and ≈øcandalous Mini≈øters; That Commi≈ø≈øioners be ≈øent from hence into all the Counties, divided into ≈øix Circuits (be≈øides London and Middle≈øex) three Commi≈ø≈øioners into each Circuit, to joyne with four or ≈øix in every County (and each riding in Yorke≈øhire to be as a County) and that in every County the ≈øaid per≈øons or five of them (two of the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øent from hence
being alway pre≈øent) be impowred to eject all Mini≈øters (of that County) that are not of good behaviour, and holy in conver≈øation, or that are not apt and able to teach, or in teaching hold not forth the faithfull word, or be not diligent, or labour not in the word and doctrine; or be greedy of filthy lucre: And be al≈øo impowred to ≈øettle godly and able per≈øons to preach the Go≈øpell in all voyd places, and to unite two or three Pari≈øhes together, ≈øo that none be above three miles from the publick Meeting-place.

2. That it be pre≈øented to the Parliament That Dr. Arrow≈ømith, Col. G ‚Ä¢ ffe, Maj. Haines, Mr. John Owen, Mr. Thomas Goodwyn, Mr. Ben of D ‚Ä¢ rche≈øter, Mr. Fairclough the elder, Mr. Lockier, Mr. Caryl, Mr. Stephen Mar≈øhall, Mr. Worthington, Mr. Turner, Mr. Tomes, Mr. Martin Holbech, Mr. Cradocke, Mr. Je≈ø≈øey, Mr. Arthur Barnid≈øton, Mr. William Greenhill. Col. Campfield, Mr. Dyke, Mr. Stalham, may be ≈øent Commi≈ø≈øioners by three in a circuit for ejecting and ≈øetling Mini≈øters, according to the Rules pre≈øcribed.

3. That all ≈øuch as are or ≈øhall be approved for publick Preachers of the Go≈øpell in the publick meeting-places, ≈øhall have and enjoy the maintenance already ≈øetled by Law, and ≈øuch other encouragement as the Parliament hath already appointed, or hereafter ≈øhall appoint: And that where any ≈øcruple payment of Tithes, the three next Ju≈øtices of the Peace, or two of them ≈øhall upon complaints call the parties concerned before them, and by the Oaths of witne≈ø≈øes, ≈øhall duely apportion the value of the ≈øaid Tithes, to be paid either in money or Land, by them to be ≈øet out according to the ≈øaid value, to be held and injoyed by him that was to have the ≈øaid Tithes; and in ca≈øe ≈øuch approved value be not duly paid or injoyed according to the Order of the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices; the Tithes ≈øhall be paid in kind, and ≈øhall be recovered in any Court of Record.

4. That upon hearing and con≈øidering what hath been offered to the Committee touching propriety in Tithes, of Incumbents, Rectors, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of Donatives, or propriate Tithes. It is the opinon of this Committe, and re≈øolved
to be reported to the Parliament, that the ≈øaid per≈øons have a legall propriety in Tithes.

The Hou≈øe having ≈øpent ≈øeverall dayes in debate of the whole Report, and e≈øpecially of the fir≈øt of the four parts thereof; and the Que≈øtion being put, That this Hou≈øe doth agree with the fir≈øt clau≈øe of the Report, it pa≈ø≈øed in the Negative.

div.head: Monday, Decemb. 12. 1653.
div.p: It being moved in the Hou≈øe this day, That the ≈øitting of this Parliament any longer as now con≈øtituted, will not be for the good of the Common-wealth; and that therefore it was requ ‚Ä¢ ≈øit to deliver up unto the Lord Generall Cromwell the powers which they received from him; and that motion being ≈øeconded by ≈øeverall other members, the Hou≈øe ro≈øe, and the Speaker with many of the members of the Hou≈øe, departed out of the Hou≈øe to White-hall, where they, being the greater number of the members ≈øitting in Parliament, did by a writing under their hands re≈øigne to his Excellency their ≈øaid Powers, and Ma≈øter Speaker, attended with the Members, did pre≈øent the ≈øame to his Excellency accordingly.

His Excellency the Lord Generall Cromwel and his Councell of Officers met this day, at which meeting, after a mo≈øt excellent, wi≈øe, gracious, and pious Speech made by his Excellency, full of Religion towards God, prudence towards the State, and love and care towards this di≈øtracted Nation, ≈øome things were tran≈øacted in order to a ≈øettlement, and ≈øweet compo≈øure; the union of all that fear the Lord is much de≈øired, that ≈øo we may ≈øit down comfortably under a ≈øafe and well grounded peace.

The late Parliament having upon their Di≈ø≈øolution delivered up the power which they received from his Excellency at their fir≈øt ≈øitting by a writing under their Hands and Seals: his Excellency thereupon called a Councell of Officers, and advi≈øed with other per≈øons of interere≈øt in the Nation, how this great burden of Governing England, Scotland, and Ireland, with the Armies therein, and Navies at Sea, ≈øhould be born, and by whom; who after ≈øeverall days ≈øeeking of God, and advi≈øing therein, it was Re≈øolved, That a Councell of
godly able and di≈øcreet per≈øons ≈øhould be named con≈øi≈øting of twenty one: And that his Excellency ≈øhould be cho≈øen Lord Protector of the three Nations. And on Friday la≈øt his Excellency came down to We≈øt: and was in≈øtolled Lord Protector of the three Nations, the manner whereof was thus.

Decemb. 18. His Excellency the Lord Generall Cromwell about one of the cock in the afternoon, went from White-hall to We≈øtmin≈øter in his Coach, foot Souldiers being on both ≈øides the ≈øtreets all along, and in the Pallace at We≈øtmin≈øter were many Souldiers both Hor≈øe and Foot; his Excellency was attended by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal of England, the Judges and Barons of the ≈øeverall Benches in their Robes, and after them the Councell of the Common-wealth: And the Lord Mayor and Aldermen of the City of London, in their Scarlet Gowns, with the Recorder and Town-Clerk, all in their Coaches, who pa≈ø≈øed before his Excellency: and la≈øt of all came his Excellency in a black Suit and Cloak in his Coach, with his Life-Guard, and divers bare before him; and many of the chiefe Officers of the Army with their Cloaks, and Swords, and Hats on, pa≈ø≈øed on foot before and about his Coach.

In this equipage his Excellency, and Attendants came to We≈øtmin≈øterhall, where was a Chair placed in the High Court of Chancery; where being come, the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal of England ≈øtood next to the Chair, the one on the one ≈øide, and the other on the other ≈øide, and next to the Lord Commi≈ø≈øioner Li≈øle who ≈øtood on the left hand of the Chair, ≈øtood his Excellency (all being bare, and his Excellency al≈øo) on every ≈øide of the Chair; in the next place ≈øtood all the Judges and Barons on both ≈øides; and the Lord Mayor & Aldermen on the right ≈øide of the Court, next unto the Judges and the Councell, and the chief Officers of the Army on the left ≈øide of the Court.

The Rules for this New Government were then read, which con≈øi≈øt of many particulars, expre≈ø≈øed in an In≈øtrument; the In≈øtrument is large, which took up above halfe an hours reading, and was read by Mr. Je≈øop, one of the Secretaries of the Councell. After which, the Lord Commi≈ø≈øioner
Li≈øle read a Parchment in the nature of an Oath, to eng ‚Ä¢ ge his Excellency to perform on his part, according to the Government before mentioned; During which t ‚Ä¢ me his Excellency held up his hand, and having beard it read accepted thereof, and ≈øub≈øcribed thereto in the face of the Court. Then the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal, and the Judges, &c. invited him to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Chair, as Lord Protector of England, Scotland, and Ireland, which he did, and ≈øate down with his head covered, the Court continuing all bare. The Lord Commi≈ø≈øioners delivered up to his Highne≈ø≈øe, the Pur≈øe and Seals, and the Lord Mayor of London his Sword, which were pre≈øently delivered to them back again by his Highne≈ø≈øe; and then after a ≈øalute, the Court ro≈øe.

Fir≈øt came the Aldermen and Councell before his Highnes, from the Court to We≈øtmin≈øter-hall Gate, where the Coaches were; after them the Judges, then came the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal, one of them bearing the Pur≈øe and Seals; and before his Highne≈ø≈øe ca ‚Ä¢ e the Life-Guard then four Serjeants of Arms with their Maces, one being the Mace of the City of London, the ≈øecond of the Chancery, the third of the Councell, and the other of the Parliament, born by the ≈øword bearer of London, Serjeant Middleton, Serjeant Dendy, and Serjeant Berkehead; and the Lord Mayor of the City of London went before his Highne≈ø≈øe with the Sword, and the Officers of the Army about his per≈øon; and in the Pallace they took Coach at the Hall Gate, and returned to White-hall in the ≈øame equipage they went; the Lord Mayor rid bare with the Sword in the Boot of the Coach with his Highne≈ø≈øe; and there were great Acclamations and ≈øhoutings all along the ≈øtreets as they pa≈ø≈øed.

His Highne≈ø≈øe the Lord Protector being returned to Whitehall, he went with his Attendants to the Banqueting Hou≈øe, where they had an Exhortation made by Mr. Lockier, Chaplain to his Highne≈ø≈øe; which bing ended, they were dimi≈ø≈øed with three Vollies of ≈øhot by the Souldiers, between four and five a clock at night.

Decemb. 19. 1653. His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, met with tho≈øe named of his Councell, in the Councell Chamber
at White-hall, it being the place where the Councell of State u≈øed to ≈øit and ≈øeverall things were Tran≈øacted in order to a ≈øettlement; and this following Proclamation was ordered to be Printed and publi≈øhed on the Monday following.

This day this Proclamation following was publi≈øhed at Westmin≈øter and in the City of London, by divers Serjeants at Arms with their Maces. The Lord Mayor and Aldermen being pre≈øent at the Exchange, &c.

div.head: By the Councell, A Proclamation.
div.p: WHereas the late Parliament di≈ø≈øolv ‚Ä¢ ng them≈øelves, and re≈øigning their Powers and Authorities, the Government of the Common-wealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, by a Lord Protector, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Trienniall Parliaments, is now e≈øtabli≈øhed; and whereas Oliver Cromwell, Captain Generall of all the Forces of this Common-wealth, is declared Lord Protector of the ≈øaid Nations, and hath accepted thereof: We have therefore thought it nece≈ø≈øary (as we hereby doe) to make Publication of the Premi≈øes, and ≈øtrictly to charge and command all and every per≈øon and per≈øons, of what quality and condition ≈øoever, in any of the three Nations, to take notice hereof, and to conform and ≈øubmit them≈øelves to the Government ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed. And all Sheriffs, Mayors, Bailiffs, and other Publick Mini≈øters, and Officers, whom this may concern, are required to cau≈øe this Proclamation to be forthwith publi≈øhed in their re≈øpective Counties, Cities, Corporations, and Market Towns, to the end none may have cau≈øe to pretend ignorance in this beha ‚Ä¢ fe. Given at Whitehall this 16 day of Decem. 1653.

div.head: December 21. 1653.
div.p: His Highne≈ø≈øe, the Lord Protector, and the Councell being thirteen in number, ≈øate in the Councell Chamber at White-hall, where his Highne≈ø≈øe in a ≈øweet Speech to them, pre≈ø≈øed the Councell to act for God, and the peace and good of the Nations; and particularly recommended to them, to con≈øider and relieve the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes of the poor and oppre≈ø≈øed: And ≈øeverall things were Tran≈øacted in order to a quiet and peaceable ≈øettlement of the≈øe three Nations.

div.head: A Declaration for alteration of ≈øeverall Names and Forms heretofore u≈øed in Courts, &c.
div.p: OLIVER, Lord Protector of the Common-wealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, and the Dominions thereunto belonging, having the exerci≈øe of the chief Magi≈øtracy, and the admini≈øtration of Government within the ≈øaid Common-wealth, inve≈øted and e≈øtabli≈øhed in his Highne≈ø≈øe, a≈ø≈øi≈øted with a Councell, who have power untill the meeting of the next Parliament (which is to be on the third of September next) to make Laws and Ordinances for the peace and welfare of the≈øe Nations, where it ≈øhall be neca≈ø≈øary, which ≈øhall be binding and in force untill order ≈øhall be taken in Parliament concerning the ≈øame.

And the ≈øaid Lord Protector finding it to be mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary that ≈øome ≈øpeedy and effectuall cour≈øe be taken for ≈øetling the Names and Forms to be u≈øed in Patents, Commi≈ø≈øions, and proceedings in Courts of Ju≈øtice, the ≈øaid L. Protector, by, and with the advi≈øe & con≈øent of his ≈øaid Councell, and in pur≈øuance of, and according to the power and tru≈øt repo≈øed in him and them, doth declare and ordain, and be it by the Authority afore≈øaid declared and ordained, That in all Courts of Law, Ju≈øtice or Equity, and in all Writs, Grants, Patents, Commi≈ø≈øions, Indictments, Informations, Suits, returns of Writs, and in all Fines, Recoveries, Exemplifications, Recognizances, Proces and Proceedings of Law, ju≈øtice or equity within the ≈øaid Common-wealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, and the Dominions thereto belonging, in≈øtead of the Name, Stile, Title, and Te≈øte (of the Keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament) heretofore u≈øed, that from and after the 26 of Decem. 1653. the Name, Stile,
Title, and Te≈øte of the Lord Protector for the time being, of the Common-wealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, and the Dominions thereto belonging, ≈øhall be u≈øed, and no other, and the date ≈øhall be in the year of our Lord and no other. And that all Duties, Profits, Penalties, I≈ø≈øues, Fines, Amercements, and Forfeitures what≈øoever, which heretofore were ≈øued for in the Name of the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, ≈øhall from and after the ≈øaid 26 of Decem. be pro≈øecuted, ≈øued forth, and recovered in the ≈øaid name of the Lord Protector, for the time being, of the Common-wealth of England Scotland, and Ireland, and the Dominions thereto belonging, and no other. And in all or any of the proceedings afore≈øaid, where the words were, The Jurors for the Common-wealth, or, The Jurors for the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, do ≈øay, or pre≈øent, from and after the 26 of Decem. it ≈øhall be, The Jurors for the Lord Protector of the Common-wealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, &c. doe ≈øay, pre≈øent, and no other, &c. And it is further Ordained by the Authority afore≈øaid, That in all Oaths to be given to any Grand or Petty Jury, or to, or for any Witne≈ø≈øes to give in Evidence to any ≈øuch Jury or Juries, and all other Oaths wherein the name of Keepers of the Liberty, &c. was wont to be u≈øed, the ≈øame ≈øhall be given in the name of the Lord Protector in≈øtead of the name of the ≈øaid Keepers, &c. any Law, U≈øage, or Cu≈øtom, to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. And it is la≈øtly Ordained by the Authority afore≈øaid, That ≈øuch Forms and cour≈øe of proceedings, as was heretofore u≈øed in the name and time of the Keepers of the Liberty, &c. in Cau≈øes criminal or civil, & of which no alteration is made in this Ordinance, ≈øhall ≈øtand and continue to be ≈øo u≈øed and ob≈øerved as formerly; & that all Indictments, Pre≈øentments, Inqui≈øitions, Commi≈ø≈øions, & Captions made with ≈øuch Alterations, Additions, or Omi≈ø≈øions as afore≈øaid, or with ≈øuch other Omi≈ø≈øions, Additions, or Alterations as ≈øhall be proper and nece≈ø≈øary for making good of Indictments Pre≈øentments, Commi≈ø≈øions, Captions, & Inqui≈øitions, and ≈øupplying the ≈øence and meaning thereof, according to the pre≈øent Government of this Common-wealth
under the Lord Protector as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall ≈øtand and be good and effectuall in Law to all intents and purpo≈øes, as if the ≈øame had been particularly herein named, any Law, Cu≈øtom or U≈øage to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding.

div.head: The Oath taken by his Highne≈ø≈øe Oliver Cromwell, LORD PROTECTOR.
div.p: WHereas the major part of the la≈øt Parliament (judging that their ≈øitting any longer, as then con≈øtituted, would not be for the good of this Com:) did d ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øolve the ≈øame, and by a writing under their hands, dated the 12 day of this in≈øtant Dec. re≈øigned unto Me their powers and Authorities; And whereas it was nece≈ø≈øary thereupon, That ≈øome ≈øpeedy cour≈øe ≈øhould be taken for the ≈øettlement of the≈øe Nations upon ≈øuch a Ba≈øis and foundation, as by the ble≈ø≈øing of God, might be la≈øting ≈øecure Property, and an≈øwer tho≈øe great ends of Religion and liberty, ≈øo long contended for; And upon full and mature con≈øideration had of the Form of Government hereunto annexed, being ≈øatisfied that the ≈øame, through divine a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, may an≈øwer the ends aforementioned: And having al≈øo been de≈øired, and advi≈øed, as well by ≈øeverall per≈øons of Intere≈øt and Fidelity in this Common-wealth, as the Officers of the Army, to take upon Me the Protection and Government of the≈øe Nations in the manner expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øaid Form of Government, I have accepted thereof, and do hereby declare My acceptance accordingly. And do promi≈øe in the pre≈øence of God, that I will not violate, and infringe the matters and things contained therein, but to My power ob≈øerve the ≈øame, and cau≈øe them to be ob≈øerved: And ≈øhall in all other things, to the be≈øt of My under≈øtanding, Govern the≈øe Nations according to the Laws, Statutes, and Cu≈øtoms, ≈øeeking their Peace, and cau≈øing Ju≈øtice and Law to be equally admini≈øtred.

postscript.p: OLIVER CROMWEL, Captain Generall of all the Forces of this Common wealth, and now declared Lord Protector thereof, did this 16 day of Decem. 1653. ≈øign this Writing and ≈øolemnly promi≈øe, as is therein contained, in pre≈øence of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal of Engl. who admini≈øtred the ≈øame Oath, and of the Lord Mayor and Alderm. of the City of London, divers of the Judges of the Land, the Officers of State and Ar ‚Ä¢ y, and many other per≈øons of Quality.

6. That the Laws ≈øhall not be altered, ≈øu≈øpended, abrogated, or repealed, nor any New Law made, nor any Tax, Charge, or Impo≈øition laid upon the people, but by common con≈øent in Parliament, ≈øave onely as is expre≈ø≈øed in the thirtieth Article.

7. That there ≈øhall be a Parliament ≈øummoned to meet at We≈øtmin≈øter upon the third day of Septemb. 1654. and that ≈øucce≈ø≈øively a Parliament ≈øhall be ≈øummoned once in every third year, to be accounted from the di≈ø≈øolution of the preceding Parliament.

8. That neither the Parliament to be next ≈øummoned, nor any ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Parliaments, ≈øhall, during the time of 5 months to be accounted from the day of their fir≈øt meeting, be adjourned, prorogued or di≈ø≈øolved without their own con≈øent.
