Worce≈øter 2. County of Worce≈øter 5. Sarum 2 Marleborough 1 Devizes 1 County of Wilts 10. Coun: of Brecon 2. County of Cardigan 2. County of Carmathen 2. Coun: of Carnarven 2. Coun: of Denbigh 2. County of Flint 2. Town of Cardiffe 1. Coun: of Clamorgan 2. Coun: of Merionoth 1. Coun: of Montgomery 2. Haverford we≈øt 1. County of Pembrook 2. County of Radnor 2.

The di≈øtribution of the per≈øons to be cho≈øen for Scotland
and Ireland, ≈øhall be according to ≈øuch proportions and number, as ≈øhall be agreed upon, and declared by the Lord Protector and the major part of the Councell, before the ≈øending forth Writs of Summons for the next Parliament, &c.

11. That the Summons to Parliament ≈øhall be by Writ under the Great Seal of England, directed to the Sheriffs of the ≈øeverall and re≈øpective Counties, with ≈øuch alteration as may ≈øuit with the pre≈øent Government, to be made by the Lord Protector and his Councel, which the Chancellor, Keeper, or Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal, ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue and ≈øend abroad by Warrant from the Lord Protector. If the Lord Protector ≈øhall not give Warrant for i≈ø≈øuing of Writs of Summons for the next Parliament, before the 1. of June, 1654. o ‚Ä¢ for the Trienniall Parliaments before the 1. day of Augu≈øt in every third year, to be accounted as afore≈øaid, That then the Chancellor, Keeper, or Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal for the time being, ≈øhall without any warrant or direction within ≈øeven dayes after the ≈øaid 1. day of June, 1654. ≈øeal, i≈ø≈øue, and ≈øend abroad Writs of Summons, &c.

12. That at the day and place of Elections, the Sheriff of each County, and the ≈øaid Mayors, Sheriffs, Bailiffs, and other head-Officers within their Cities. Towns, Burroughs and places re≈øpectively, ≈øhall take view of the ≈øaid Elections, and ≈øhall make return into the Chancery within twenty dayes after the ≈øaid Elections, &c. wherein ≈øhall be contained, that the per≈øons elected ≈øhall not have power to alter the Government as it is hereby ≈øetled in one ≈øingle per≈øon and a Parliament.
13. That the Sheriff, who ≈øhall wittingly and willingly make any fal≈øe return or neglect his duty, ≈øhall incur the penalty of two thou≈øand Marks.

14. That all and every per≈øon and per≈øons, who have aided, advi≈øed, a≈ø≈øi≈øted or abetted in any war again≈øt the Parliament ≈øince the fir≈øt day of January, 1641. (unle≈ø≈øe they have been ≈øince in the ≈øervice of the Parliament, and given ≈øignall te≈øtimony of their good affection thereunto) ≈øhall be di≈øabled and uncapable to be elected, or to give any Vote in the Election of any Members to ≈øerve in the next Parliament, or in the three ≈øucceeding Trienniall Parliaments.

15. That all ≈øuch, who have advi≈øed, a≈ø≈øi≈øted, or abetted the Rebellion of Ireland, ≈øhall be di≈øabled and uncapable for ever to be Elected, or to give any Vote in the election of any Member to ≈øerve in Parliament; as al≈øo all ≈øuch who doe or ≈øhall profe≈ø≈øe the Roman Catholick Religion.

16. That all Votes and Elections given or made contrary, or not according to the≈øe Qualifications, ≈øhall be null and void: And if any per≈øon who is hereby made uncapable, ≈øhall give his Vote for Election of Members to ≈øerve in Parliament, ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øhall lo≈øe and forfeit one full years value of his reall E≈øtate, and one full third part of his per≈øonall E≈øtate.

17. That the per≈øons who ≈øhall be elected to ≈øerve in Parliament, ≈øhall be ≈øuch (and no other then ≈øuch) as are per≈øons of known integrity, fearing God, and of good conver≈øation, and being of the age of 21 years.

18. That all and every per≈øon and per≈øons ≈øeized or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed to his own u≈øe, of any e≈øtate reall or per≈øonall, to the value of 200 l. and not within the afore≈øaid exceptions ≈øhall be capable to elect Members to ≈øerve in Parliam. for Counties.

19. That the Chancellor, Keeper, or Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal, ≈øhall be ≈øworn before they enter into their Offices, truly and faithfully to i≈ø≈øue forth, and ≈øend abroad Writs of Summons to Parliaments at the times and in the manner before expre≈ø≈øed: And in ca≈øe of neglect or failer to i≈ø≈øue and ≈øend abroad writs accordingly, he or they ≈øhall for every ≈øuch offence be guilty of High Trea≈øon, and ≈øuffer the paines and penalties thereof.

20. That in ca≈øe writs be not i≈ø≈øued out as is before expre≈øt, but that there be a neglect therein, fifteen days after the time wherein the ≈øame ought to be i≈ø≈øued out by the Chancellor, Keeper or Commi≈ø≈øioners of the great Sea that then the Parliament ≈øhall, as often as ≈øuch failer ≈øhall happen a≈ø≈øemble and be held at We≈øtmin≈øter, in the u≈øuall place, at the times prefixt, &c.

21. That the Clerk, called the Clerk of the Commonwealth, in Chancery for the time being and all others, who ≈øhall afterwards execute that Office, to whom the Returns ≈øhal be made, ≈øhall for the next Parliament, & the two ≈øucceeding Trieniall
Parliaments, the next day after ≈øuch Return, certifie the names of the ≈øeveral per≈øons ≈øo returned, and of the places for which he and they were cho≈øen re≈øpectively, unto the Councel who ≈øhall peru≈øe the ≈øaid Returns, and examine whether the per≈øons ≈øo Elected and Returned, be ≈øuch as is agreeable to the Qualifications, & not di≈øabled to be Elected: And that every per≈øon and per≈øons being ≈øo duly Elected, and being approved of by the major part of the Councell to be per≈øons not di≈øabled, but qualified as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall be e≈øteemed a Member of Parliament, and be admitted to ≈øit in Parliament, and not otherwi≈øe.

22 That the per≈øons cho≈øen and a≈ø≈øembled in manner afore≈øaid, or any ≈øixty of them, ≈øhall be, and be deemed the Parliament of England, Scotland, & Ireland, and the Supream Leg ‚Ä¢ ≈øl ‚Ä¢ tive power to be and re≈øide in the Lord Protector and ≈øuch Parliament, &c.

23. That the Lord Protector, with the advice of the major pa t of the Councel, ≈øhall at any other time then is before expre≈øt, when the nece≈ø≈øities of the State ≈øhall require it, ≈øummon Parliaments in manner before expre≈øt, which ≈øhall not be adjourned, prorogued, or di≈ø≈øolved without their own con≈øent, during the fir≈øt three months of their ≈øitting. And in ca≈øe of future war with any Forreign State, a Parliam. ≈øhall be forthwith ≈øummoned for their advice concerning the ≈øame.

24. That all Bills agreed unto by the Parliament, ≈øhall be pre≈øented to the Lord Protector for his con≈øent; and in ca≈øe he ≈øhall not give his con≈øent thereto, within twenty dayes after they ≈øhall be pre≈øented to him, or give ≈øatisfaction to the Parliament within the time limited; That then upon Declaration of the Parliament, that the Lord Protector hath not con≈øented nor given ≈øatisfaction, ≈øuch Bills ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe into, and become Laws, although he ≈øhall not give his con≈øent thereunto; provided ≈øuch Bills contain nothing in them contrary to the matters contained in the≈øe pre≈øents.

25. That Phillip L. Vi≈øcount Li≈øle, Charls Fleetwood E≈øq; John Lambert E≈øq; Sir Gilbert Pickering Baronet, Sir Charls Wool≈øley Bar. Sir Anthony A≈øhley-Cooper Bar. Edw: Montagu E≈øq; John Desbrow E≈øq; Walter Strickland E≈øq; Henry Lawrence
E≈øq; William Sydenham E≈øq; Phillip Jones E≈øq; Rich: Major E≈øq; Francis Rous E≈øq; Phillip Skippon E≈øq; or any ≈øeven of them ≈øhall be a Councell for the purpo≈øes expre≈øt in this Writing; and upon the death or other removall of any of them, the Parliament ≈øhall nominate ≈øix per≈øons of Ability, Integrity, and fearing God, for every one that is dead or removed, out of which the major part of the Councell ≈øhall elect two, and pre≈øent them to the Lord Protector, of which he ≈øhall elect one, &c.

26. That the Lord Protector and the major part of the Councell afore≈øaid, may at any time before the meeting of the next Parliament, add to the Councell ≈øuch per≈øons as they ≈øhall think fit; provided the number of the Councell be not made thereby to exceed 21, and the Quorum to be proportioned accordingly by the Lord Protector and the major part of the Councell.

27. That a con≈øtant yearly Revenue ≈øhall be rai≈øed, ≈øetled and e≈øtabli≈øhed for maintaining of ten thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Dragoons, and twenty thou≈øand Foot, in England, Scotland, and Ireland, for the defence and ≈øecurity thereof, and al≈øo for a convenient number of Ships for guarding of the Seas; be≈øids two hundred thou≈øand pound per annum for defraying the other nece≈ø≈øary Charges for admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice, and other expences of the Government; which Revenue ≈øhall be rai≈øed by the Cu≈øtoms and ≈øuch other wayes and means as ≈øhall be agreed upon by the Lord Protector & the Councel, and ≈øhall not be taken away or dimini≈øht, nor the way agreed upon for rai≈øing the ≈øame altered, but by the con≈øent of the Lord Protector and the Parliament.
28. That the ≈øaid yearly Revenue ≈øhall be paid into the publick Trea≈øury, & ≈øhall be i≈ø≈øued out for the u≈øes afore≈øaid.

29. That in ca≈øe there ≈øhall not be cau≈øe hereafter to keep up ≈øo great a Defence at Land or Sea, but that there be an abatement made thereof, the mony which will be ≈øav'd thereby, ≈øhall remain in bank for the publick Service, and not be imployed to any other u≈øe but by con≈øent of Parliament; or in the intervals of Parliament by the Lord Protector and major part of the Councell.

30. That the rai≈øing of money for defraying the charge of pre≈øent extraordinary Forces both at Land and Sea, in re≈øpect of the pre≈øent wars, ≈øhall be by con≈øent in Parliament and not otherwi≈øe: Save onely that the Lord Protector, with the con≈øent of the major part of the Councell, for preventing the di≈øorders and dangers which may otherwi≈øe fall out both at Sea and Land, ≈øhall have power untill the meeting of the fir≈øt Parliament, to rai≈øe money for the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, and al≈øo to make Lawes and Ordinances for the peace and welfare of the≈øe Nations, where it ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary, which ≈øhall be binding and in force, untill Order ≈øhall be taken in Parl. concerning the ≈øame.

31. That the Lands, Tenements, Rents, Royalties, Juri≈ødictions and Hereditaments which remain yet un≈øold or undi≈øpo≈øed of by Act or Ordinance of Parliament, belonging to the Common-wealth (except the Forre≈øts and Cha≈øes, and the Honors and Mannors belonging to the ≈øame; the Lands of the Rebels in Ireland, lying in the four Counties of Dublin, Corke, Kildare, & Katerlaugh, the Lands forfeited by the people of Scotland in the late wars, and al≈øo the Lands of Papi≈øts and Delinquents in England who have not yet compounded) ≈øhall be ve≈øted in the Lord Protector, to hold, to him and his Succe≈ø≈øors Lord Protectors of the≈øe Nations, and ≈øhall not be aliened but by con≈øent in Parliament. And all Debts, Fines, I≈ø≈øues, Amerciaments, penalties and profits, certain and ca≈øuall, due to the Keepers of the Liberties of Engl: by Authority of Parliament, ≈øhall be due to the Lord Protector, and be payable unto his publick Receipt, and ≈øhall be recovered and pro≈øecuted in his Name.

32. That the Office of the Lord Protector over the≈øe Nations, ≈øhall be Elective and not Hereditary; and upon the death of the Lord Protector, another fit per≈øon ≈øhall be forthwith Elected, to ≈øucceed him in the Government, which Election ≈øhall be by the Councell, &c. Provided that none of the Children of the late King, nor any of his Line or Family, be Elected to be Lord Protector or other chief Magi≈øtrate over the≈øe Nations, or any the Dominions thereto belonging. And untill the afore≈øaid Election be pa≈øt, the Councell ≈øhall take care
of the Government, and admini≈øter in all things as fully as the Lord Protector, or the Lord Protector and Councell are inabled to doe.

33. That O. Cromwell, Captain Generall of the Forces of England, Scotland, and Ireland, ≈øhall be, and is hereby declared to be Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, and the Dominions thereto belonging, for his life.

34. That the Chancellor, Keeper, or Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Great Seal, the Trea≈øurer, Admirall chiefe Governors of Ireland and Scotland, and the chiefe Ju≈øtices of both the Benches, ≈øhall be cho≈øen by the approbation of Parliament; and in the intervalls of Parl. by the approbation of the major part of the Councell, to be afterwards approved by the Parl.

35. That the Chri≈øtian Religion contained in the Scriptures be held forth & recommended as the publick profe≈ø≈øion of the≈øe Nations; and that as ≈øoon as may be, a provi≈øion, le≈ø≈øe ≈øubject to ≈øcruple and contention, and more certain then the pre≈øent, be made for the encouragement and maintenance of able and painfull Teachers, for in≈øtructing the people, and for di≈øcovery and confutation of Error, Here≈øie, and whatever is contrary to ≈øound Doctrine: And that untill ≈øuch provi≈øion be made, the pre≈øent maintenance ≈øhall not be taken away nor impeached.

36. That to the publick profe≈ø≈øion held forth, none ≈øhall be compelled by penalties or otherwi≈øe, but that endeavors be u≈øed to win them by ≈øound Doctrine, and the example of a good conver≈øation.

37. That ≈øuch as profe≈ø≈øe Faith in God by Je≈øus Chri≈øt (though differing in judgement from the Doctrine, wor≈øhip, or Di≈øcipline publickly held forth) ≈øhall not be re≈øtrained from, but ≈øhall be protected in the profe≈ø≈øion of the Faith, and exerci≈øe of their Religion; ≈øo as they abu≈øe not this liberty, to the civill injury of others, and to the actuall di≈øturbance of the ‚Ä¢ ublick peace on their parts, provided this liberty be not extended to popery nor prelacy, nor to ≈øuch as under the profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt hold forth and practi≈øe licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe.

38. That all Laws, Statutes, Ordinances and Clau≈øes in any
Law, Statute and Ordinance to the contrary of the afore≈øaid Liberty, ≈øhall be e≈øteemed as null and void.

39. That the Acts and ordinances of Parliament, made for the ≈øale or other di≈øpo≈øition of the Lands, Rents and Hereditaments of the late King, Queen and Prince, of Arch-Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, &c. Deans and Chapters, the Lands of Delinquents, and Fore≈øt Lands, or any of them, or of any other Lands, Tenements, Rents and Heriditaments belonging to the Common-wealth, ≈øhall no wayes be impeached or made invalid, but ≈øhall remain good and firme: And that the Securities given by Act and Ordinance of Parliament for any ≈øum or ≈øums of mony, by any of the ≈øaid Lands, the Exci≈øe, or by any other publick Revenue; and al≈øo the Securities given by the publick Faith of the Nation, and the engagement of the publick Faith for ≈øatisfaction of Debts and Damages, ≈øhall remain firm and good, and not be made voyd and invalid upon any pretence what≈øoever.

40. That the Articles given to, or made with the Enemy, and afterwards confirmed by Parliament, ≈øhall be performed and made good to the per≈øons concerned therein. And that ≈øuch appeals, as were depending in the la≈øt Parliament, for reliefe concerning Bils of ≈øale of Delinquents E≈øtates, may be heard and determined the next Parl. any thing in this writing, or otherwi≈øe to the contrary notwith≈øtanding.

41. That every ≈øucce≈ø≈øive L. Protector over the≈øe Nations, ≈øhall take and ≈øub≈øcribe a ≈øolemn Oath, in the pre≈øence of the Councell, & ≈øuch others as they ≈øhall call to them that he will ≈øeek the peace, quiet, and welfare of the≈øe Nations, cau≈øe law and Ju≈øtice equally to be admini≈øtred, and that he will not violate or infringe the matters and things contained in this writing; and in all other things will to his power, and to the be≈øt of his under≈øtanding, govern the≈øe Nations according to the Laws, Statutes, and Cu≈øtoms.

42. That each per≈øon of the Councel ≈øhall, before they enter upon their Tru≈øt, take, & ≈øub≈øcribe an Oath, That they will be true and faithfull to their Tru≈øt, according to the be≈øt of their knowledge; and that in the election of every ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Lord Protector, they ≈øhall proceed therin impartially, and do nothing therein for any promi≈øe, fear, favour, or reward.

div.head:
Aprill 25. 1654. Four Ordinances were publi≈øhed touching Scotland.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ting Scoctland into one Common-wealth with England St Andrews ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o≈ø≈øe ye Scots Arms be born in the Arms of this Common-w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢
coat of arms of the Commonwealth
div.p: THirty per≈øons to be called from Scotland in every Parliament. That Charls Stewart, and all of the late Kings po≈øterity, be di≈øabled to enjoy the Crown of Scotland, or Name, Title, Stile, Dignity, Honors, or any Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of any Hereditaments thereto belonging; As al≈øo the Convocation of the three E≈øtates of Scotland to be aboli≈øhed. That Cu≈øtom and Exci≈øe of Goods, be no otherwi≈øe between England and Scotland, then from one place of England to another. That Taxes be proportionable to England. And that all Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of Lands after Apr. 12. 1654. ≈øhall hold their Lands of the Lords, by Deed, Patent, or Enfeoffment, to be renewed upon the death of every Heritor to his Heirs, under ≈øuch Rents, and Services as are due by Deeds now in being, without rendring any other duty, ≈øervice, va≈ø≈øalage or demand what≈øoever, except Heritors where the ≈øame are due. A Court Barron every three weeks, to Judge all Contracts, Debts, Promi≈øes, and Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes not exceeding 40 s. ≈øterling.

July 1. 1654. The High Court of Ju≈øtice met in We≈øtmin≈øter-hall, the Lord Com. Li≈øle ≈øate as Pre≈øident, their Commi≈ø≈øion was read, and the Court called over by their names; Mr. Atturney Gen. Prideaux, Mr. Sollicitor Gen. Ellis, and Mr. Serjeant Glin, were Coun≈øell for his Highne≈ø≈øe the Lord Protector. The Lieut. of the Tower, fir≈øt brought Mr. Somer≈øet Fox, one of the Con≈øpirators in the late Trea≈øon, to the Bar, and Mr. Atturney Gen. then pre≈øented a Charge of High Trea≈øon again≈øt him ingro≈ø≈øed in parchment to the Court, which was read: The Pri≈øoner ≈øaid very little to it, but made a Confe≈ø≈øion to the Court of ≈øo much as (he ≈øaid) he was guilty of, having ≈øome few dayes before made the like confe≈ø≈øion, and given it under his hand as the tru h, and accordingly owned it in Court, his confe≈ø≈øion under his own hand was al≈øo read, which did di≈øcover what was his part to act as an Agent in this bloody de≈øigne. The Court having ≈øatisfied th ‚Ä¢ m≈øelves concerning Mr. Fox, the Lievt. of the Tower brought Mr. John Gerrard, and Mr. Peter Vowell, to the Bar, where F ‚Ä¢ x al≈øo ≈øtood, and the like Charge of High Trea≈øon was read again≈øt them al≈øo; which Charge con≈øi≈øted of the≈øe heads, viz. The murdering of his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector as he ≈øhould go to Hampton Court on a Saterday prefixt: The ≈øeizing of all the Guards about Whitehall, the Mews, & St. Jame≈øes, & the making of them≈øelves ma≈øters of the City of London, and the Tower with all the Magazines within the ≈øame: The proclaiming of Charls Stuart King, & chief Magi≈øtrate of England, Scotland, and Ireland, and the Dominions thereunto belonging, and other high Trea≈øons tending to involve the Common-wealth in a new bloody war. To which charge of High Trea≈øon the ≈øaid Gerard and Vowel pleaded Not guilty, pretending much ignorance, and that they were innocent of the knowledge of any ≈øuch de≈øigne; and did very much pre≈ø≈øe the Court to grant them Coun≈øell to advi≈øe withall, and that they might be tried by a Jury, which being not to be granted unto them, and waved, ≈øeverall Witne≈ø≈øes were produced upon their Oaths to make appear what they were charged with, as John Wi≈øeman, Dr. Hud≈øon, a blind man, Mr. Charls Gerhard Brother to the Pri≈øoner, Capt. Dale, one
Mr. Wharton, and others, who did ≈øufficiently prove, That Mr. Gerrard was to command the party who were to murder his Highne≈ø≈øe the L. Protector as he was going to Hampton Court with thirty Hor≈øe; and that the ≈øaid Gerrard had engaged to bring 25 of the 30, and Maj. T: Hen≈øhaw was to bring 5 more: and it was al≈øo proved again≈øt him, that he, with Maj. Hen≈øhaw, and the Witne≈ø≈øe J. Wi≈øeman, did view the ≈øeverall Guards at Whitehall, the Mewes, and St. Jame≈øes, and had computed and de≈øigned 600 Hor≈øe as ≈øufficient to ≈øeize and ≈øecure tho≈øe Guards, appointing al≈øo a party of Hor≈øe to march into Tuttle-fields, as friends, and ≈øo to fall upon the forces then mu≈øtering, and cut them off: It was al≈øo proved again≈øt him by his Brother Mr. Charles Gerrard, that he was at ≈øeverall meetings at his own Chamber near E≈ø≈øex hou≈øe, and at other places with Maj. Hen≈øhaw, and Finch, and others, about this de≈øigne, and particularly at Mr. Jones his Hou≈øe in Ro≈øe ≈øtreet in Covent Garden where in a Chamber Hen≈øhaw and Finch gave an account that they had each of them li≈øted 800 men to be ready at a dayes warning; ≈øeverall other things were proved, which he ob≈øtinately denied; but confe≈øt his name was much u≈øed therein, but was no intent Actor. And for Mr. Vowell, ≈øeverall Witne≈ø≈øes upon their Oaths did te≈øtifie, that he was at many meetings with Hen≈øhaw, Finch, Gerhard, and other of the Plotters to contrive the management of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, being a per≈øon thought more fit to be a Councellor, then an Actor, and his reward ≈øhould have been to be Ma≈øter of Suttons Ho≈øpitall; and it was al≈øo proved again≈øt him, though he could not act him≈øelfe, yet he promi≈øed to procure tho≈øe that ≈øhould act, and did engage one Capt. Billing≈øley, who undertook to provide Riders for the Hor≈øes who ≈øhould be taken out of I≈ølington fields; it was al≈øo proved his buying of Pi≈øtols, and many other things ≈øufficient to prove his hand deep in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. And for Somer≈øet Fox, he confe≈ø≈øed ≈øo much as ≈øaved the Court much trouble in examining witne≈ø≈øes: His part was, to engage as many Apprentices and Citizens of London as he could in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, that ≈øo when the falling on was upon the Guards at White hall, the Mewes and
St. Jame≈øes, and Col. Ingeldsbies Regiment in Southwark and the re≈øt of the Plot was in agitation, there might be a ri≈øing and tumult made purpo≈øely in the City, to imploy what force was there, that no help might come el≈øewhere; and the Lord Mayor was to have been ≈øeized and carried to proclaim Charls Stuart King at the Exchange, and Dr. Wharton was to ≈øee him proclaimed: yet notwith≈øtanding all the≈øe witne≈ø≈øes, Gerhard and Vowell denyed they knew of any thing of ≈øuch a de≈øigne; but they were not ≈øo ≈øatisfied, but that a ba≈øe de≈øign was intended, too unworthy for a Gentleman to have his hand in, as did further appear by the te≈øtimony of John Wi≈øeman, who did relate his going over into France with his brother in Law Maj. Hen≈øhaw, where they met the ≈øaid Mr. Gerhard at Paris, and there had free acce≈ø≈øe to the pretended King of Scots, about this de≈øigne, and received great encouragement in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe from Prince Rupert; whereupon Hen≈øhaw and Wi≈øeman returned into England, and Mr. Gerhard came over about 3 weeks after to put the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in agitation, immediately upon his arrivall, the ≈øaid Hen≈øhaw, Finch, &c. repaired to his lodging near E≈ø≈øex hou≈øe, and received an account of the bu≈øines, and ≈øo proceeded to act, as the ≈øaid Wi≈øeman te≈øtified. The Witne≈ø≈øes being all examined, and the Pri≈øoners heard what they could ≈øay for them≈øelves, the Attorney Gen. Solicitor Gen. and the Councell for the Commonwealth ≈øumm'd up all the Evidences, and drew them into ≈øeverall heads, which they pre≈øented to the Court with the Pri≈øoners at the Bar, as objects of their Ju≈øtice, the ≈øaid Gerhard and Vowell ≈øtill remaining ob≈øtinate. The Pri≈øoners were commanded back to the Tower.

July 6. The Portugall Amba≈ø≈øadors Brother, and the re≈øt, we ‚Ä¢ e againe brought to their Tryall at the ∆≤pper Bench at We≈øtmin≈øter and a Jury of 12 men, whereof 6 Denizes and 6 Aliens Impannel'd and ≈øwore: The Amba≈ø≈ø: Brother pleaded very hard his ignorance in the Lawes of England, and de≈øired Councell, but that was denied, and he told, That the Court were of Councell equall, and alike to him, as to the Common-wealth, and would doe according to Law and the Ju≈øtice of the Cau≈øe; Hereupon many Witne≈ø≈øes were
≈øworn and examined, and upon full hearing of the Evidence, and what the Pri≈øoners could ≈øay, the Jury withdrew, and in a ≈øhort time returned, and delivered their Verdict by their Foreman (all agreeing) finding them all 5 guilty of the murther and Felony for which they ≈øtood indicted; whereupon Judgement was afterwards pronounced, after a ≈øhort ≈øpeech made by the L: Chief Ju≈øtice Rolls in the name of the Court, That they ≈øhould return from whence they came and from thence be carried to the place of Execution, & there ≈øeveally to be hanged by the neck till they are dead. The day appointed Saturday, but the Pri≈øoners moved for re≈øpite till Monday, which was granted.

This afternoon al≈øo the High Court of Ju≈øtice ≈øat in We≈øtmin≈øter-hall, and there was brought before them Mr. Gerard, Mr. Vowel, and Mr. Fox, who were demanded what they had more to ≈øay for them≈øelves, Gerhard and Vowell ≈øpake much to excu≈øe them≈øelves, notwith≈øtanding what had been proved again≈øt them; after which the L. Pre≈øident Li≈øle made a learned ≈øpeech, to convince them of the de≈øperate wickedne≈ø≈øe of their de≈øigne, and how fully the Charge had been proved, and what puni≈øhments the Law had provided in ≈øuch ca≈øes, after which the Sentence of the Court was read ≈øeverally to all three, to this effect, That upon mature con≈øideration of the Trea≈øons and Murthers plotted, and contrived, by them again≈øt his Highne≈ø≈øe the Lord Protector, and the Common-wealth, and rai≈øing a bloody war in the ≈øame, the Court did adjudge them to be hanged by the neck untill they be dead. Mr. Gerhard de≈øired the Execution might be altered, that he might be beheaded or ≈øhot to death, and therefore petitioned to the Lord Protector.

About 4 in the afternoon, Mr. John Gerhard was brought to the Scaffold on Tower-hill, his behaviour was ≈øprightly, the ≈øub≈øtance of his di≈øcour≈øe Cavalier-like, boa≈øting him≈øelfe of the profe≈ø≈øion of Religion which was e≈øtabli≈øhed by Queen Elizabeth, K. James, and Charls, to which family he declared his affection. He acknowledged him≈øelf guilty of former ≈øins (but named them not) for which he had de≈øerved death heretofore; but as touching the Crime for which he was to
die, he ≈øpent not many words, onely he confe≈ø≈øed that he knew of the plot. At length he ≈øubmitted his neck to the Executioner, who at once ≈øevered the Head from the Body.

div.head:
July 10. 1654. Don Pontaleon Sa, Brother to the Portugall Amba≈ø≈øador, and Mr. John Gerhard, were both beheaded at Towerhill.
depiction of a beheading at Tower Hill
div.p:
But a little before he lay down, came the Portugal Amba≈ø≈øadors Brother, Don Pontaleon Sa. A very ob≈øervable hand of Providence that the≈øe two per≈øons, Gerhard and the Don, who began that quarrell, in the pro≈øecution whereof the murther was committed at the New Exchange, ≈øhould meet thus to die at the ≈øame time and place, for different crimes. It is al≈øo to be noted, that God did even mark out this Portugall for Ju≈øtice; for when he e≈øcaped out of Newgate at fir≈øt, he was immediately found out: and now having by Order of the Court been remanded to the Keeper of Newgate, he was very near an e≈øcape thence againe, but the Lord prevented him: For ye≈øternight, being Lords day at night, a new plot
was laid for his e≈øcaping by two women, one was Mrs. Gourdon who brought another woman, who under her womans apparrell had a Foot-boys ≈øuit on; the womans cloths being taken off, they dre≈øt up the Don in them, and ≈øo he came down with Mrs. Gourdon, to to the door, where the Keeper narrowly prying under the hood, di≈øcovered the fraud, and ≈øpoyled the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. This failing, and the hour of execution next day approaching, he was conveyed from Newgate to Tower hill in a Coach and ≈øix Hor≈øes in mourning having divers of of his Brothers retinue with him, much lamenting his condition. Being upon the Scaffold, he ≈øpake ≈øomewhat to tho≈øe that under≈øtood him, in excu≈øe of his offence, laying the blame of the quarrell and murther upon the Engli≈øh. So after ≈øome few private words and pa≈ø≈øages of Popi≈øh devotion with his Confe≈ø≈øor, he ≈øurrendred to him his Beads and Crucifix, and his Head to the Block, which was chopt off with ≈øomewhat more then a ≈øingle blow. The re≈øt condemned about th t murther, were reprieved all, ≈øave an Iri≈øh man, who was executed al≈øo this day early in the morning, at Tiborn.

In the morning al≈øo of this day, the Articles of Peace being fully concluded betwixt England and Portugall, were ≈øigned by the ≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øador, and immediately thereupon he withdrew from his hou≈øe out of Town.

It plea≈øed his Highne≈ø≈øe to reprieve Somer≈øet Fox, becau≈øe of his ingenuous confe≈ø≈øion, but this day the other two were executed for their Trea≈øons again≈øt his Highnes and the Commonwealth. Vowel a School-ma≈øter, was in the morning executed upon a Gallows at Charing-Cro≈ø≈øe, and in the ≈øame place it was expected Gerhard ≈øhould have ≈øuffered the ≈øame death, but he had the favour granted him to loo≈øe his head: Vowel ≈øpake little of the crime for which he ≈øuffered, but the main of his di≈øcour≈øe was to proclaim how great a Zelot he was to the old way of Religion, and to the cau≈øe of the late King and his family; wherein he let fall divers expre≈ø≈øions tending to ≈øedition, and few of repentance for his fault touching which he would not ≈øpeak out, but willed the Executioner to doe his Office, and ≈øo after halfe an hours hanging he was cut down, and conveyed away in a Coach.

div.head: The form of an Indenture between the Sheriff, and the E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ctors of Per≈øon, to ≈øe ‚Ä¢ ve in Parl. for Counties. depiction of Parliament
div.p:
THis Indenture made the _____ day of _____ in the year of our Lord, one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fifty and four, at _____ in the County of _____ Between _____ Sheriff of the County afore≈øaid of the one part, and C. D. E. F. G. H. and divers other per≈øons qualified and capable to Elect Members to ≈øerve in Parliament for Counties, as is pre≈øcribed in the Goverment of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, witne≈ø≈øeth, That Proclamation having been made in every Market-Town in the County afore≈øaid, within ten dayes after the receit of a certain Writ of the Lord Protector to the afore≈øaid Sheriff directed, and to one part of the≈øe Indentures annexed for the Election of _____ Knights, fit and di≈øcreet per≈øons of the County afore≈øaid, for the Parliament of the ≈øaid Lord Protector, in the Writ afore≈øaid ≈øpecified to be cho≈øen, and to be at the Parliament of the ≈øaid Lord Protector, at We≈øtmin≈øter in the County of Middle≈øex, the third day of September next to be held; The afore≈øaid C. D. E. F. G. H. &c. and divers other Per≈øons of the County afore≈øaid, who were pre≈øent at ≈øuch Election, freely and indifferently have cho≈øen _____ Knights girt with Swords, that is to ≈øay, A. B. &c. to be in the Parliament afore≈øaid, as in the ≈øaid Writ is mentioned, who for them≈øelves, as al≈øo for all the People of the County afore≈øaid, have full and ≈øufficient power to doe and con≈øent unto tho≈øe things, which in
the afore≈øaid Parliament ≈øhall then and there, by common con≈øent and councell, happen to be ordained. Provided, and it is hereby Declared, That the per≈øons ≈øo cho≈øen ≈øhall not have power to alter the Government as it is now ≈øetled in one ≈øingle per≈øon and a Parliament. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof, as well the Seal of the Office of the ≈øaid Sheriff, as al≈øo the Seals of the Electors afore≈øaid, the day, year, and place above≈øaid, to the≈øe Indentures are put and affixed.

div.head: The form of an Indenture between the Sheriff, and the Burge≈ø≈øes and Inhabitants of Burroughs.
div.p: THis Indenture made the _____ day of _____ in the year of our Lord, one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fifty and four, Between A. B. High Sheriff of the County of _____ of the one part, and C. D. E. F. G. H. &c. Burge≈ø≈øes and Inhabitants of the Burrough of _____ of the other part, witne≈ø≈øeth, That by vertue of a Warrant unto J: K: _____ of the ≈øaid Burrough of _____ from the ≈øaid High Sheriff to him directed, for the Electing and choo≈øing of _____ Burge≈ø≈øes of good under≈øtanding, knowledge and di≈øcretion for Cau≈øes concerning the publick good of this Commonwealth, To be at his Highne≈ø≈øe Parliament to be ‚Ä¢ olden at We≈øtmin≈øter the third day of September next; we the ≈øaid Burge≈ø≈øes and Inhabitants there, have made choice and election of L. and M. to be Burge≈ø≈øes of the ≈øaid Burrough of _____ to attend at the ≈øaid Parliament according to the tennor of the ≈øaid Warrant unto him the ≈øaid I. K. directed in that behalfe; who for them≈øelves and people of the ≈øaid Burrough have full power to doe and con≈øent to tho≈øe things which in Parliament ≈øhall happen: Provided they alter not the Government from one ≈øingle per≈øon and a Parliament. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof we the parties above named to the≈øe pre≈øents interchangeably ≈øet our hands and Seals, the day and year fir≈øt above written.

div.head: January 22. 1654.
div.p: The five months (according to the in≈øtrument of the Government for the time allotted to ≈øit) being expired, his Highne≈ø≈øe the Lord Protector ≈øent a me≈ø≈øage to them to meet him in the Painted Chamber, about 12 of clock; where they being met, he made a ≈øpeech about two hours lo ‚Ä¢ g for the di≈ø≈øolving of the Parliament, and ≈øo declared than he did di≈ø≈øolve them.

figure.head: Charles by ye grace of God, Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwell, etc.

div.p:
YOu will ea≈øily believe that I am very well per≈øwaded, to hear how carefull and ≈øolicitous you are for my concernments, and of the cour≈øe you re≈øolve to take: The truth is, I have been ≈øo tender of my friends, that I have deferred to call upon them to appear, till I could find my ≈øelfe able to give them good incouragements from abroad; but
≈øince I find that comes on ≈øo ≈ølowly, I would no longer refraine tho≈øe affections, which I mu≈øt de≈øire to be beholding to; and have rea≈øon to believe, that if they who wi≈øh one and the ≈øame thing, knew each others minds, the work would be done without any difficulty, and if there were any hand≈øome appearance in any one place, the re≈øt would not ≈øit ≈øtill, and I am per≈øwaded I ≈øhould then find ≈øupplies from tho≈øe who are yet afraid to offer them; however I am ≈øure I would my ≈øelfe be with tho≈øe that fir≈øt wi≈øhed for me, and to that purpo≈øe I would keep my ≈øelfe within a rea≈øonable di≈øtance. Con≈øult with tho≈øe you dare tru≈øt, if you are already ag ‚Ä¢ eed upon a time, and you cannot promi≈øe your ≈øelves any thing that you will be di≈øappointed in, and which is in the Power of

div.head: March 13. 1655.
div.p: THis day his Highne≈ø≈øe, as al≈øo the Members of the Councell, and the Officers of the Army, were bu≈øie about the Plot, and to ≈øubdue the ri≈øings in ≈øeverall places.
All the Hor≈øes about London were this day ≈øeized on by Order from his Highne≈ø≈øe and the Councell, to prevent any ri≈øing here.
This evening ≈øome hundred of Armes where brought into Whitehall from the Tower by water in Boats, Backs, and Bre≈øts, and Swords, which are there ready as occa≈øion ≈øhall offer for u≈øe.

His Highne≈ø≈øe and the Councell ≈øate very late (untill after midnight) this night, making all po≈ø≈øible means for ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of all tumults and in≈øurrections, touching which ≈øeverall Commi≈ø≈øions, and In≈øtructions, and Letters, were di≈øpatched to the ≈øeverall Counties, to the end the Common-wealth
may be e≈øtabli≈øhed in Peace, that tho≈øe who are ri≈øen may be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and to prevent the like in other places.

div.head: A Relation of the ≈øeverall Ri≈øings, the truth whereof is as followeth.
div.p: THere were ≈øome Cavaliers ≈øaid to be ri≈øen about Merioneth ≈øhire, and other parts in Wales, reported in all to be 7 or 8 hundred, but not like to be ≈øo many of that party, for ≈øome of tho≈øe that ri≈øe in Wales were Inhab ‚Ä¢ tants to oppo≈øe any that ≈øhould ri≈øe as was feared, which intended to joyne with tho≈øe of the Army.

Another party were ri≈øen in Nottingham ≈øhire, noi≈øed to be 500, but not thought ≈øo many, towards whom a party from Col. Hacker marched out of Leice≈øter ≈øhire to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe them; their intent was thought to be, to have joyned with another party at Shrewsbury which were di≈øcovered, and ≈øo their de≈øigne fru≈øtrated.

There were four men to go into Shrewsbury Ca≈øtle, two in womans apparrell, and the other two as their men to wait on them; who being got in, at a ≈øea≈øonable time were to give notice by ≈øhooting off a Pi≈øtoll to a party of hor≈øe which they were to let in, and ≈øo ≈øurprize the Ca≈øtle, of which Collonell Mackworth, one of the ≈øons of the old Collonell Mackworth decea≈øed, now the Governour, having notice, prevented their de≈øigne; and hath apprehended the Lord Newport, one White, Sir Thomas Harris, and ≈øeverall of the Actors: about 100 hor≈øe were found in a Barn, and the Armes under ≈øtraw in the ≈øame Barn, which are taken, and tho≈øe parts ≈øecured. Che≈øter was al≈øo intended to be ≈øeized on.

Tho≈øe that were ri≈øen in Nottingham ≈øhire ≈øo ≈øoon as they had an Alarm from Collonell Hackers Troops marching again≈øt them from Leicester ≈øhire, the chiefe of the Cavaliers met in con≈øultation what to doe, and pre≈øently re≈øolved to di≈øper≈øe and be gone; becau≈øe they were prevented of joyning with tho≈øe intended to have ri≈øen at Shrewsbury, and
that a party of the Army were marching towards them, and they had no ≈øecurity to retreat any where; the Countries about not ri≈øing as was expected, but rather oppo≈øing them: It was debated what they ≈øhould doe with their Armes, for they had received a Cart load of Armes, ≈øome would have had them thrown into the water, but it was re≈øolved to have them ≈øent back to the hou≈øe from which they were ≈øent to them, which accordingly was done, and the Cavaliers di≈øper≈øed pre≈øently upon it; and ≈øome of the chief of them are apprehended, and the Armes ≈øeized on.

div.head: Yorke. March 26. 1655.
div.p: Sir Richard Maliverer, on Thur≈øday night la≈øt, ≈øent for all his Tennants to a great Supper, and then invited them all to joyne with him in taking up Armes, and told them they intended that night to take Yorke for the King, and appointed them a gate where he would meet them, ≈øome four went along with him, divers Gentlemen met them upon He≈ø≈øay More, and Carts laden with Armes; after they had been there a while, the appearance was ≈øo ≈ømall, to what was expected, that they parted againe. Sir Richard Maliverer went home, and bid his Lady to take the be≈øt cour≈øe ≈øhe could for her ≈øelfe, for he was nece≈ø≈øitated to flye, wi≈øhing him≈øelfe well arrived beyond the Seas, and ≈øo departed from her.

div.head: The Intelligence touching the Cavaliers that were at Salisbury, is as followeth.
div.p:
THe Judges came to Salisbury on Saterday la≈øt, being met by Mr. Dove the High Sheriff and his men, and that divers of the Cavaliers came into the Town, it being a time (as they ≈øuppo≈øed) of lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpicion. On the Lords day about midnight the Cavaliers randezvouzed, and were above 100. Monday morning early they ≈øeized all the hor≈øes, ≈øeized on the Sheriff about ≈øeven a clock, would have forced him to proclaime Charles Stewart King, which he refu≈øing,
they wounded him in ≈øeverall places, cut him over the face with a ≈øword, knocked him over the head with a pi≈øtoll, yet he told them he would loo≈øe his life before he would doe it, and though he offered them money and other offe ‚Ä¢ s, yet they took him away. The Commander in chief was one Sir Jo≈øeph Wagstaffe, formerly a Lieut. Collonell, at the beginning of the late wars, in the Parliaments Army; but now revolted to the late King, was a Collonell under him; a ‚Ä¢ d now Major Generall to this intended Brigade for Charls St ‚Ä¢ wart. And they plundred both the Judges, the Sheriff, the Ju≈øtices, the Lawyers, and Gentlemen, and all, of all they coul ‚Ä¢ get fit to carry away; But afterwards one Penruddock told the Judges that Maj. Gen. Wagstaffe had given o ‚Ä¢ ders to a≈ø≈øure them, that they ≈øhould receive no harm in their own per≈øons. After that they had taken from the Judges their Paroll, they let out the pri≈øoners, ≈øome for debt (as Mr. Gokin who was in for 1000 l. and others) and all the Theeves and malefactors, with their Irons upon them, mounted tho≈øe that would joyne with them, and went out (after they had proclaimed Charls Stewart King) being about 200. And from thence went to Blanford, incouraging their followers, that their chiefe Leader was comming from France to head them with 10000 men, for they began to be di≈øcouraged that the Country people did not ri≈øe and joyne with them as was expected; ≈øo that ≈øome of them have left them, among which ≈øome of them are come to Whitehall to beg pardon. They went from thence towards Dorche≈øter.

The chief are ≈øaid to be,
M. Gen. Sir Jo≈øeph Wag≈øtaffe
Sir Henry More of Berkshire
John Penruddock E≈øq;
Maj. Henry Clark E≈øq;
Thomas Mumpar≈øons
Lieut. Col. Boll
Capt. Hugh Grove,
Two of the Jone≈øes, &c.
There are divers of them taken.

list.item: Mr. John Dean, And Mr. Lucas,

div.p: Were Executed, at the appointed places, on Thur≈øday and Friday la≈øt, at Salisbury and Exce≈øter, being the 3 and 4 of this in≈øtant May, 1655.

Sir William Ingram, Sir Walter Vava≈øor, Sir Hen: Slingsby, and divers other Gentlemen, are ≈øu≈øpected to have had an hand in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; a party of hor≈øe is gone this morning to ≈øecure ≈øuch as can be found: Sir William Ingram is brought in already.

div.head: Part of the In≈øtructions and Orders given to the Major Generalls for pre≈øerving the Peace of the Common-wealth, are as followeth.
div.p:
THey are to endeavor the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing all Tumults, In≈øurrections, Rebellion, or other unlawfull A≈ø≈øemblies, which ≈øhall be within the ≈øaid Counties, as al≈øo all Inva≈øions from abroad, and to that purpo≈øe ≈øhall have power to draw together
the ≈øaid Forces or Troops, and march into ≈øuch places as they ≈øhall judge convenient in England and Wal ‚Ä¢ s.

They are to take care and give order, That all Papi≈øts and others who have been in Armes again≈øt the Parliament, or a≈ø≈øi≈øted the late King or his Son in the late Wars, as al≈øo all others who are dangerous to the peace of the Nation, be di≈øarmed, and their Arms ≈øecured in ≈øome adjacent Garri≈øons, or otherwi≈øe di≈øpo≈øed of, as may be for the publick ≈øervice.

And to the end that the Highways and Roads may be more ≈øafe for Travellers, and the many Robberies and Burglaries daily comm ‚Ä¢ tted may be prevented They, with the ≈øaid Captains and Officers ≈øhall u≈øe their be≈øt endeavors to find out all ≈øuch Thieves, Robbers, Highway-men, and other dangerous per≈øons as lurk & lie hid in any place within the ≈øeveral Counties, and the hou≈øes and places which they frequent and u≈øually lodge in, and take ≈øuch cour≈øe for the apprehending of them, and al≈øo for the pro≈øecuting them and their Receivers, as is agreeable to Law. And they have hereby power to appoint ≈øuch reward, not exceeding ten pounds, to ≈øuch per≈øon as ≈øhall di≈øcover and apprehend any ≈øuch Thief, Highway-man or Robber, to be paid unto them after the conviction of the party ≈øo di≈øcovered and apprehended, which the Sheriff for the time being ≈øhall pay, and which ≈øhall according to an Act of Parliament, entituled, An Act for the better and more effectual di≈øcovery and pro≈øecution of Thieves & Highway-men, be allowed to him upon his account.

They are to have a ≈øtrict eye upon the Conver≈øation and carriage of all Diaffected per≈øons within the ≈øeveral Counties. And they ≈øhall give the like direction to all the ≈øaid Captains and Officers at their Meetings, to be watchfull and diligent in the ≈øame kind: As al≈øo that no Hor≈øe-races, Cock-fightings, Bear-baitings, Stage-plays, or any unlawfull A≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ mblies be ≈øuffered or permitted within their Counties. Fora≈ømuch as Trea≈øon and Rebellion, is u≈øually hatched and contrived again≈øt the State upon ≈øuch occa≈øions, and much Evill and Wickedne≈ø≈øe committed.

They and the afore≈øaid Officers, ≈øhall labor to informe them≈øelves of all ≈øuch idle and loo≈øe people that are within
their Counties, who have no vi≈øible way of Livelihood, nor calling or imployment, and ≈øhall con≈øider by what means they may be compelled to work, or be ≈øent out of the Common-wealth: As al≈øo how the poor and impotent of tho≈øe Counties may be imployed, and better provided for, then now they are, and certifie the ≈øame to us, and the Councell, for our further Direction thereupon. And in the mean time, ≈øhall endeavor as far as in them lies, that the Laws in ≈øuch ca≈øes, made and provided, be put in effectuall Execution.

They ≈øhall in their con≈øtant Carriage and Conver≈øation, encourage and promote Godline≈ø≈øe and Vertue, and D ‚Ä¢ ≈øcourage and Di≈øcountenance all Prophane≈ø≈øe and U ‚Ä¢ godline≈ø≈øe; and ≈øhall endeavor with the other Ju≈øtices of the Peace, and other Mini≈øters and Officers, who are intru≈øted with the care of tho≈øe things that the Laws again≈øt Drunkenne≈ø≈øe, Bla≈øpheming, and taking of the Name of God in vaine, by ≈øwearing and cur≈øing, Plays and Interludes, and prophaning the Lords day, and ≈øuch like wickedne≈ø≈øe and abominations, be put in more effectuall execution then they have been hetherto.
